Posts.Content: Nov 8, 2007 09:02AM JapanLynn wrote: Hi-- I just got home from my last rads treatment, and I'm an absolute basket case!  I had been fine through the whole thing...no problems at all...and when they put me on the table today for my last boost, I could feel myself starting to tear up.  When the nurses and techs hugged me, I just lost it!  Cried all the way home and I'm still crying. Part of my problem, I think, is that I've been here in NY for treatment, staying with my wonderful sister and her family; they've been so good to me.  On the 18th I leave to go back to Japan, where I live and work.  Even though my sister is only a phone call away, and I have many, many wonderful and supportive friends/colleagues there, I'm worried about how I'll handle getting back to "real life"...if today is any indication, I don't think I'll do too well. This afternoon I see my oncologist for the last time before leaving...I know it'll be the same soggy, blubbery scene again.  Next Tuesday, it's the surgeon's turn to see me break down.  Then I'll leave my sister...  I just feel like my supports are being taken away, one by one. I know I'll be fine once I get back and get into the swing...I haven't posted much here even though I've lurked a lot.  I have a feeling y'all will be hearing much more from me. Thanks for listening...Lynn

Posts.Content: Feb 6, 2008 07:01PM JapanLynn wrote: I couldn't agree more with Twink.  I was offered valium after signing the consent and before SN mapping, that wire thing in the boob (radiation brain strikes again...sorry), and my lumpectomy.  Like Twink, I said "Hell, yeah" too!  Better living through chemistry is my motto in such situations.  It's a stressful time, and if a little something will take the edge off, ask for it.  Apparently there were no bleeding problems...I didn't even have to have drains put in.  Do what you need to do to get through this time.  Good luck to you, Beth! Lynn

Posts.Title: OK...the docs have a plan. AlaskaDeb LuAnnH

Posts.Content: Oct 20, 2007 07:38AM JapanLynn wrote: Hi, Kaye-- I'm halfway through radiation so thought I'd share my experience.  My breast surgeon recommended a rad. onc. at a different hospital from where I had my surgery.  I love my surgeon, and she described this woman rad. onc. as "head and shoulders above the rest."  My sister and I made an appt. with her and schlepped to her clinic...about 25 miles away.  The dr. was wonderful, the clinic was nice, and her credentials were great--she had trained at one of the big hospitals in NYC, had recently written a textbook on rad. oncology, etc.  Seemed like the best choice, right? The downside of this place...a 50-mile round trip every day, partly on an interstate under construction with horrible traffic; and there was construction everywhere with parking almost nonexistent.  Still, I thought I should come here because of this woman's sterling rep. For a 2nd opinion, I made an appt. at the cancer center at the hospital where I had my surgery.  It's a beautiful, new place, with a young dr. who had also trained in NYC.  The drive was 20 miles round trip through a beautiful forest with the leaves changing color.  The center has complimentary treatments like acupuncture and massage.  There's reserved parking for patients up front that costs $1 daily, no matter how long you're there. Guess which one I chose?  While I still felt a little like I was settling I just couldn't make that long drive every day.  When I talked to my medical onc., who I love, about which one to go to, he said the center I chose actually had the newest radiation equipment--newer than the first place.  My humble opinion...since you're going to be schlepping there every day for at least six weeks, there are multiple factors to be considered.  I figure that anyone who's board certified in rad. onc. is going to be fine, if everything else works for you.  Boy--I really rambled.  Sorry...good luck with your decision! Lynn

Posts.Content: Mar 14, 2009 11:13PM JapanLynn wrote: Hi, Bernice-- I'm way down south in Sasebo.  A cheaper option would be going to the local hospital and having a CT scan.  Japanese medicine as a whole isn't on a par w/ ours, but they should be able to handle that.  I had one last fall at the local hospital...thought I had a blood clot in my leg (I didn't, thank heavens), but the whole emergency room visit, including CT scan w/ and w/out contrast, was 40,000 yen--a fraction of the cost in the states.  Just curious--Tricare won't foot the travel bill for you to go where the proper care is available?  That is, if you can get a base doc to agree that a CT scan is what you need.  Good luck! I'm doing fine...just went to Yokosuka a couple of weeks ago for my 6-mo. mammo, which was clear.  I'm on Tamoxifen, which causes some joint pain and whatnot, but all in all, I can't complain.  Hope your problem turns out to be minor, but it's best to get things checked out. Take care...Lynn

Posts.Content: Jun 26, 2008 06:55AM JapanLynn wrote: Thinking of you, Laura... Everybody is right...this IS the worst part of the whole thing.  Now you need to get a medical team in place that you trust and will help you get a treatment plan in place.  Don't be afraid to get second opinions on everything; good, competent drs. aren't threatened by this.  Listen, ask questions of your drs. and here, and decide what the best course is for you. The shock of hearing those words--"You have cancer"--wears off somewhat and you'll be energized to find out your options.  This is a great site...lots of wisdom and caring here.  Let us know what's happening.  Sending prayers and good karma your way-- Lynn

Posts.Content: Dec 21, 2007 04:33PM - edited Dec 21, 2007 04:34PM by JapanLynn Jump-- You can never go wrong with a 2nd opinion.  Like Beesie said, I was totally sold on my surgeon (she had taken over the practice from my previous surgeon who retired) and had confidence in her, but my sister, a nurse, urged me to get a 2nd opinion.  I went to another highly regarded surgeon and he seconded all the info I had been given before.  A plus--his way of explaining the sentinel node biopsy, which I was more than a little fuzzy on after the 1st explanation--made perfect sense with the analogies he used.  I urge you to go to the most respected breast surgeon in your area you can find for your 2nd...whether or not friends and relatives agree w/ your choice.  Good luck to you! Lynn

Posts.Content: Jan 1, 2009 09:07PM JapanLynn wrote: I'm with you, Jenny--no need to see the multitude of drs who were involved in treatment unless there's a real reason.  I finished radiation about 14 months ago, and never went back for a follow-up...just didn't see a good reason.  I liked my radiation onc, loved the center and techs where I had treatment, but I have no issues with my skin or anything else.  I see my medical onc yearly, and also my surgeon; that's plenty.  The last time I saw the plastic surgeon--halfway through radiation--she said, "I'll see you in six months."  I asked my breast surgeon if I needed to see her again and she said no. Copays get expensive, and our time is worth something, too.  Happy New Year! Lynn

Posts.Title: Eeek - a CORD! I'm freaking out... Kleenex knowledgeforpower

Posts.Content: Dec 22, 2007 07:41PM JapanLynn wrote: Jump-- I've read in numerous places through this journey, and I agree completely w/ this, that if a dr. is offended because you want a 2nd opinion, run--don't walk--to another dr.  Someone in the medical field who doesn't understand the million emotions that come with a cancer diagnosis, and the desire to get as much info as possible, is not someone you want handling your care. As women, I think we get the impression that it's up to us to keep everybody happy and on an even keel; not to disappoint anyone.  That's the message I've always gotten, but it went out the window w/ my diagnosis.  I was feeling like you at the beginning of the process of assembling a medical team, but my sister, a retired nurse, convinced me that no dr. should feel slighted by my going to someone else for an opinion.  All the doctors I saw, either 1st or 2nd, were supportive of my fact-finding, and no one seemed offended in the least.  Unfortunately, there are more than enough cancer patients to keep all of them very busy. Just encouraging you to go with whoever you click best with, Jump.  Good luck! Beesie, your diagram was very helpful.  Thank you! Lynn
